name: Git
description: Git helps you keep track of changes in your files and work with others on the same project.

snippets.title: Install Git (Windows)
snippets.codeDes: Download Git from the official website (https://git-scm.com/) and follow the installation instructions. After installation, open Command Prompt and run the following command to verify the installation.

snippets.title: Install Git (Mac)
snippets.codeDes: Install Git using Homebrew, a package manager for macOS. Open Terminal and run the following commands to install Git and verify the installation.

snippets.title: Install Git (Linux)
snippets.codeDes: Install Git using your Linux distribution's package manager. Use the appropriate command for your system (e.g., apt for Ubuntu/Debian, yum for RedHat/CentOS). After installation, run the following command to verify the installation.
snippets.code:
sudo apt install git  # Ubuntu/Debian
sudo yum install git  # RedHat/CentOS
git --version

snippets.title: Set Up Git Username and Email
snippets.codeDes: Configure Git with your name and email address, which will be used to label your commits. Replace 'Your Name' and 'your-email@example.com' with your actual name and email address.
snippets.code:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your-email@example.com"

snippets.title: Check Git Settings
snippets.codeDes: Display your current Git configuration settings, including your username and email address, to ensure they are set correctly.

snippets.title: Create SSH Key
snippets.codeDes: Generate a new SSH key pair for secure authentication with GitHub. Replace 'your-email@example.com' with your email address. Follow the prompts to save the key and optionally set a passphrase.

snippets.title: Add SSH Key to GitHub
snippets.codeDes: Display the contents of your public SSH key file. Copy the output and add it to your GitHub account under Settings > SSH and GPG keys.

snippets.title: Test SSH Connection
snippets.codeDes: Test your SSH connection to GitHub to ensure your SSH key is set up correctly. You should see a success message indicating that you have successfully authenticated.

snippets.title: Start a New Git Project
snippets.codeDes: Initialize a new Git repository in your current directory. This will create a .git directory and start tracking changes in your project.

snippets.title: Check Project Status
snippets.codeDes: Display the status of your working directory and staging area, showing which files have been modified, added, or deleted.

snippets.title: Save a File for Commit
snippets.codeDes: Stage a specific file for commit, adding it to the list of changes to be saved. Replace 'filename.txt' with the name of the file you want to stage.

snippets.title: Save All Changes
snippets.codeDes: Stage all modified and new files in your working directory for commit, adding them to the list of changes to be saved.

snippets.title: Commit Your Changes
snippets.codeDes: Commit the staged changes to your repository with a descriptive message explaining what you did. Replace 'Initial commit' with your own message.

snippets.title: See Commit History
snippets.codeDes: Display a concise list of all commits in your repository, showing the commit hash and message for each commit.

snippets.title: Link to GitHub
snippets.codeDes: Add a remote repository on GitHub to your local Git repository. Replace 'https://github.com/your-username/your-repo.git' with the URL of your GitHub repository.

snippets.title: Upload Changes to GitHub
snippets.codeDes: Push your committed changes to the remote repository on GitHub. The '-u' flag sets 'origin main' as the default upstream branch for future pushes.
snippets.code:
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

snippets.title: Download a Project
snippets.codeDes: Clone a GitHub repository to your local machine, creating a copy of the repository in a new directory. Replace 'https://github.com/your-username/your-repo.git' with the URL of the repository you want to clone.

snippets.title: Get Latest Changes
snippets.codeDes: Fetch and merge the latest changes from the remote repository on GitHub into your local repository. This updates your local project with any new commits from the 'main' branch.
